review_title: don't look away, it might change again
pros: Potential for camaraderie within lower levels of faculty and staff. Pretty campus.
cons: The local community and on-campus culture are both isolating and elitist. Efforts for forward progress are met with moral high ground or diversity posturing. Upper management and employee population are not in communication, nor do they strive for the same goals. Do not be surprised by changes in job titles/roles without warning, budget cuts to reallocate funds to other areas that mismanage resources, and inappropriate handling of Title IX/harassment/confidentiality issues within a team and from HR. Education and experience levels as well as rapport with a team have little impact on promotion or job opportunities--beware of "shared vision" and "we are a family" language. Lowest tiered employees are given the brunt of additional projects and workload with the expectation of being team players without compensation for added effort to support management at the immediate supervisor and executive levels. I served in multiple offices alongside staff and faculty, and these norms exist across the organization. A lot of higher ed institutions are struggling with funding, but as a professional that has served several institutions, these funding and culture issues are BEYOND standard industry challenges at this time.

review_title: Abusive and cruel to those not seen as a cultural fit
pros:
1) Health insurance.

2) Tuition waivers for full-time employees (although I think new restrictions for this benefit will be implemented in the future).
cons:
Arkansas Tech University is an employer conducive to a culture of workplace mobbing, bureaucratic dysfunction, and poor leadership.

Success at this university depends primarily on one’s social attributes as well as preexisting relationships with hiring officials, supervisors, and anyone carrying influence at the institution.  Being seen as a cultural fit at Arkansas Tech supersedes educational qualifications, skill sets, and previous work experience when it comes to the hiring process.  In the last couple of years, the university has also dramatically enhanced and enforced its call for diversity which, in basic terms, means a new form of discrimination and prejudice in selecting candidates to fill positions.  Again, superficial criteria are oftentimes a primary factor in the hiring process.

As a former full-time employee within an academic department at ATU for nearly four years, I witnessed the rise of political factions and the callous and deliberate ousting and/or demotion of employees that stood out from others for one reason or another which in turn made them targets of bullying and gossip.

I met the same fate during the final months of my employment.  For reasons unknown to me, I became the target of a faculty mob.  My guess is that I unintentionally bruised someone’s ego at some point.  I generally worked independently and kept a low profile.  My introverted and non-confrontational demeanor likely made me vulnerable to predators.  For a number of months, I faced passive aggressiveness and subtle bullying tactics by a group of four faculty members in my department.

I learned the hard way that performance evaluations and performance improvement plans (PIPs) can arbitrarily be made and used to open the door through which to push any employee out of the workforce.  One month before my employment ended, I was broadsided with news that I had been dealt a scathing review of my job performance and had been placed on a period of probation.  In my case, for example, following three consecutive years of positive reviews, I learned suddenly that I was not taking lunch breaks at the right hour, that I was not adding enough posts to the department’s Facebook page, and that I was not making full use of my student workers among other frivolous items.  None of these items had been addressed to me prior to the evaluation, nor was I ever advised that I should take lunch at a certain hour, to meet a specific quota of Facebook posts, or precisely what it meant to make full use of student office workers.  I usually took lunch breaks when I came to a satisfying stopping point between tasks or projects – I always went to lunch for an hour between 11am to 1pm – I did so for more than three years without receiving a complaint.

On a late afternoon during the last week of my employment, a group of faculty members, led by the department head, came into the main office where I worked and, without speaking one word to me, began disassembling my desk during the middle of a work project.  They reassembled the desk in a different section of the main office in front of a large window opening facing the hallway and directly in front of the elevator doorway.  I asked the department head why he was doing this and requested some distance away from the elevator doors.  In an effort to reason with him, I stated that I wouldn’t mind being closer to the front of the office, but that being next to the elevator doors as well as the hallway foot traffic would likely be a distraction and may have a negative impact on my productivity.  He responded by pointing a finger at the desk, coldly saying, “the department needs you there.”  Three days later, the department head, accompanied by an interim dean, walked into the main office while I worked.  He handed me a letter and asked me to read it then and there.  The letter notified me that he had deemed it improbable that I would successfully complete the demands of my performance improvement plan and stated that I must leave immediately as it was my last day with Arkansas Tech University.   The department head and the faculty mob had framed me as a difficult employee for questioning the relocation of my workspace.  Furthermore, Human Resources provided no help or guidance to me throughout these troubling events even when I mentioned a problem to them.

The cruelty and humiliation of those experiences were tremendous.  I’ve never been in a work environment so toxic and abusive.  It has severely damaged my attitude and support for academia.   What’s worse is that I am an alumnus of that university.  I earned both my bachelor’s and master’s degrees there.  I feel utterly mutilated and let down.
